children.subject: +1 to everything said above except I found 135 to be one of the most fundamental classes for statistics.

Sorry if I didn't make it clear, 135 is in theory really helpful but I had Ibser and a horrible course staff that made me decide to not take another stat class for two years. 135 is definitely useful, I'm just both jaded and didn't learn a ton from my experience in it.
Makes sense. I too would suggest to avoid Ibser (had him for stat 20)

The only thing I'd add is that Stat 140 (Probability for Data Science) is a fantastic class which you should check out. It's been taught only by Professor Adhikari so far and is easily one of the best classes I've taken at Berkeley.

Also you can skip 133 if you take Data 100 and Stat 33B

I was a CS and Stats double and I guess the first thing worth mentioning is that there's EECS126 that's heavily pushed if you're CS. Since I was stat I never took it, but anyway. Stat 134 is awesome if you can take it with Adhikari, but sadly she rarely teaches it anymore. I found 135 much less interesting but also had a horrible lecturer/course staff, the main thing that I took out of it was something called an MLE that is very useful in an future statistical inference classes (including a lot of ML). 133 is a waste of time that we've been petitioning to skip and I believe there's some way to now if you're CS. 153 is pretty valuable from a data analysis point of view, 151a is great for building an in depth understanding of what regression is actually all about, 102 is a pretty fun class (way better than data 100 in my opinion and significantly more mathy), then I did the special topics 157/260 with Prof. Brown who's awesome. The big thing with the stat department is it's just not organized as well as CS. I have theories as to why, but it's usually 4-5 GSIs and maybe 1-2 will actually care about teaching. Expect to get homeworks back 1-2 months after turning in, exams 2-3 weeks. Professors/Lecturers are very hit and miss. Adhikari is amazing, I avoid Ibser at all costs. Jared Fisher is pretty good for 153, as is Sam Pimentel for 151a. Then it's cool when Mike Jordan teaches 102. Overall I hated 133 and 135 and loved 134, then I learned to ask around about professors and classes way more because stat classes are subject to a good bit more variation than CS in the quality of the class in my opinion. After I figured that out I had much better experiences with the 150s

history.content:
Anyone here is Stats & CS double major?

I see lots of connections between courses in two departments, would you like to share/rate/comment on the courses you take? 

Thanks!
